DADOS-GERAIS.NOME-EM-CITACOES-BIBLIOGRAFICAS: GRUETER, C.;GRUTER, C.;Grter, C.;GRTER, Christoph;GRTER, C.;GRTER, CHRISTOPH

RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH: I am a behavioural ecologist who studies social insects. My main interests are communication and learning in foraging ants and honeybees, and division of labour and nest-mate recognition in stingless bees (Meliponini). Currently, I work as an assistant professor at the University of Mainz in Germany.

MESTRADO.TITULO-DA-DISSERTACAO-TESE: Biparental care in the mouth-brooding cichlid Eretmodus cyanostictus

DOUTORADO.TITULO-DA-DISSERTACAO-TESE: Social Learning of Food Odours in Honeybees: Mechanisms and Implications for Collective Foraging

POS-DOUTORADO.NOME-AGENCIA: Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Cientfico e Tecnolgico

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Organisation of collective work in insect societies
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
Insect colonies simultaneously perform different tasks like brood care, nest building, foraging or nest defence. Because the external environment and internal conditions of a colony change over time workers need to adjust their behaviour according to the changing needs of the colony. For example, nest damage requires the allocation of more workers to nest building, raising temperatures induce more foragers to collect water for cooling etc. Understanding how insect colonies solve this organisational challenge caused by the constant change in colony needs is a major challenge for evolutionary ecologists. Workers are able to acquire information from their local environment and adjust their behaviour according to simple decision rules. As a consequence of these individual responses, collective behavioural patterns emerge at higher organisational levels, e.g. the optimal distribution of foragers in the colony environment or division of labour (DOL) in insect societies. This process is called self-organisation (SO).
In recent years researchers have uncovered unexpected richness and sophistication in the signals and information used by workers in colony organisation. Individuals can use an array of information provided by their nest-mates (social information, e.g. antennation, dances or other excitatory behaviours, pheromone trails) and acquire information during direct interaction with the environment (private information, e.g. food source locations, nest climate). In the past, most research has focused on one type of information at a time. However, insect workers often face more than one type of information at the same time and understanding decision-making in these situations is fundamental in order to understand SO of work in insect societies.
Decision-making processes based on local information often lead to division of labour, a key feature of insect societies. Individuals specialize to perform particular tasks either for their entire life or a certain period. DOL is supposed to increase work efficiency via task specialisation. However, this assumption has rarely been tested and it is often not clear how DOL increases efficiency in insect societies, especially in species lacking morphologically differentiated worker castes.
In this project we studied the organisation of two collective tasks, foraging in honeybees (Apis mellifera) and the common garden ant (Lasius niger) and nest defence in the stingless bee Jata (Tetragonisca angustula). We investigated decision-making in the face of multiple information sources in foraging and the adaptive significance of DOL in nest defence. Specifically, we tested (1) whether social and private information are processed strictly hierarchically or whether foragers can select the best information use strategy depending on the quality of the different options. Furthermore, we tested (2) if social and private information can act together and increase foraging efficiency of workers. In the context of nest defence we studied (3) how division of labour in nest defence improves the detection of intruders and robbers. Furthermore, we investigated whether T. angustula has a morphologically specialised guard caste. This has not yet been found in social bees. The work on T. angustula was performed at Fazenda Aretuzina, Brazil, in collaboration with Prof. Ratnieks and Prof. Vera Imperatriz-Fonseca from the University of Sao Paulo, Brazil.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Organisation of collective work in insect societies

INTEGRANTES-DO-PROJETO.NOME-PARA-CITACAO: GRUETER, C.;GRUTER, C.;Grter, C.;GRTER, Christoph;GRTER, C.;GRTER, CHRISTOPH

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Decision making in social insects when facing multiple information sources
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
Understanding the organisation of complex social tasks in insect species without central control is a major challenge for evolutionary ecologists. Insights will help to explain the fascinating collective behavioural patterns that can be observed in social insects, for example during foraging or nest hunting, and the insects? ecological success. In this process of self-organisation individuals can use an array of information sources - e.g. antennation, dances or other excitatory behaviours, pheromone trails, socially transmitted food source specific chemosensory information and self-acquired experiences - and act upon this information.
Usually studies focus on one sensory channel or information source at a time, but rarely on how different kinds of information act together. In this project I studied decision making in 3 different insect species, the honeybee (Apis mellifera), the black garden ant (Lasius niger) and the Pharaoh?s ant (Monomorium pharaonis) in the face of multiple information sources. Under natural circumstances, these different kinds of information can complement each other in order to enhance foraging success. In the group of Prof. Francis Ratnieks, I tested whether different types of (simultaneously available) information are processed hierarchically and how experience and information quality modulate decision making.
Specifically, I (1) investigated how the quality of familiar food sources and the quality of private information regarding the location of a familiar food source affect the use of location information provided by honeybees performing waggle dances. (2) I studied whether L. niger workers which can use 2 types of social information plus private information about the location of a food source prioritise one type of information over the other ones. Furthermore, (3) tested how the quality of information regarding the polarity of a pheromone trail network affects the trail choice behaviour of Pharaoh?s ants.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Decision making in social insects when facing multiple information sources

INTEGRANTES-DO-PROJETO.NOME-PARA-CITACAO: GRUETER, C.;GRUTER, C.;Grter, C.;GRTER, Christoph;GRTER, C.;GRTER, CHRISTOPH

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: The adaptive significance of communication and learning for colony success in honeybees
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Insect societies, like human societies and many other complex biological systems need an efficient regulation of collective tasks to achieve optimal system performance. In social insects different groups of workers perform these vital collective tasks, such as brood rearing, nest-defence or foraging. Insect colonies also show an impressive ability to adapt to sudden changes in the environment by means of positive and negative feedback mechanisms, which lead to the reallocation of workers to new tasks or cause recruitment of inactive workers to locations where work is needed. Attractive and inhibitory pheromones produced by foraging ants or bees are examples of such positive and negative feedbacks. Key to this process of dynamic self-organisation is the ability of workers to acquire, process and act upon information from their local environment. Therefore, in order to understand self-organisation of insect societies one needs to understand how individual workers use information to adjust their behaviour and how these decision-making rules increase the efficiency of the overall system. The best studied context of self-organisation is social foraging and a wide range of social information cues and signals that are involved in foraging regulation have been identified in the last century. Apart from social information, that is information provided by other nest-mates, workers also use information acquired directly during interactions with the environment, such as spatial memories about good food source locations, that is private information. Alternatively, workers might ignore both social and private information and try to locate completely new food sources, often called scouting. Our understanding of how individual foragers use different simultaneously occurring information sources has improved in recent years. However, there is still a lack in understanding of how important different kinds of information are for system performance, i.e. how individual information-use and decision-making strategies affect collective success. This is needed to understand the adaptive significance of information for colony performance and, therefore, the selection pressures that led to the evolution of different communication systems. This project will address this gap in understanding and test the importance of key information sources for system performance, using ecologically and economically important model systems, European and tropical honey bees. We use observational, experimental and theoretical approaches. We study the link between individual information-use and collective performance in the context of honey bee foraging. To this end, we investigate the role of spatial communication (social information; the waggle dance) and learning ability (private information; tactile appetitive learning) for foraging success, mainly measured as honey and brood production. Because the value of information about the environment is likely to depend on the characteristics of this environment, we explore if social or private information are more relevant under certain conditions, such as a stable versus an unpredictable foraging environment

INTEGRANTES-DO-PROJETO.NOME-PARA-CITACAO: GRUETER, C.;GRUTER, C.;Grter, C.;GRTER, Christoph;GRTER, C.;GRTER, CHRISTOPH

PARTICIPACAO-EM-PROJETO.NOME-ORGAO: Faculdade de Filosofia Cincias e Letras de Ribeiro Preto

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Evolutionary and chemical ecology of nest defence in a stingless bee with a soldier caste (Tetragonisca angustula)
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: The nests of insect colonies contain many valuable resources including adults, brood, food stores such as honey and nest material, and even the nest site itself. The stingless bee Tetragonisca angustula (Jata) shows several exceptional adaptations in defensive organisation. These include the existence of hovering guards (Wittmann 1985; Wittmann et al. 1990; Bowden et al. 1994; van Zweden et al. 2011), the exceptionally low error rate in nestmate/non-nestmate recognition (Krcher & Ratnieks 2009; Jones et al. 2012) and a physically specialised defence caste (soldiers) (Grter et al. 2012). In this project we tried to better understand the effectiveness of this nest-defence. We investigated the importance of guard size for nest-mate recognition ability. We also quantified the relationship between guard size and the number of olfactory pore plates on the antennae of entrance guards. We extracted the cuticular hydrocarbons (CHC) of bees of different worker groups of different colonies from two different populations to see how they differed between worker group and colonies. The chemical profiles will also allow us to explore whether the level of aggression of guards towards foragers of other colonies is related to the difference in CHC profiles between colonies. Additionally, we performed morphometric measurements of Jata workers in Paran and Belm to confirm that colonies in these locations also have morphologically specialised soldiers.

INTEGRANTES-DO-PROJETO.NOME-PARA-CITACAO: GRUETER, C.;GRUTER, C.;Grter, C.;GRTER, Christoph;GRTER, C.;GRTER, CHRISTOPH
